DOC.brief_summary: - Phantom limb pain (PLP) refers to pain in a limb that has been amputated or deafferented. Phantom limb pain might be related to brain cortical plastic changes. - The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a series of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) sessions, a non-invasive and focal brain stimulation method, in producing long-term reduction of phantom limb pain among amputees who experience such pain. This is a Crossover sham control.
DOC.brief_title: Long-term Effects of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) on Patients With Phantom Limb Pain (PLP)
DOC.criteria: Age 18 to 80 Limb amputation from at least 6 months before study enrollment Presence of PLP at least 2 times a week and present 4 weeks prior to onset of study Written informed consent Coexistence of major neurological or psychiatric diseases Being actively enrolled in a separate study targeting pain relief Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) diagnosed patients Any contraindication to noninvasive brain stimulation such as past brain surgery, brain implants, cochlear implant, epilepsy or any past seizure Pregnant women Within the traumatic amputees group subjects diagnosed with diabetes
